page.title: 18CORSTON BEACON
page.content: The excavation of the round cairn at Corston Beacon was very exciting. The cairn was a round pile of stones with a flattish top. When the stones were removed the excavators found a most unusual burial. The grave was lined with stone slabs and covered with another about 2m. long. Only one person had been buried in the grave. All that was left were parts of the thigh bones. The man must have been an important chief for there was a flat knife or dagger, with holes showing where it had once been riveted to a handle of wood or bone, buried with him. It was made of bronze, and is one of the earliest metal weapons ever found in Wales. It is now in the National Museum in Cardiff.
